Next year I want to try something with a strong flavour, I’ll probably pick something from Southern Italy because they experiment the most with flavours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pandoro is good but it’s boring, it’s just a soft brioche that tastes like vanilla and butter, you’d be happier with a fresh bakery croissant with a more complex texture and layers with an exterior crust that crunches.

Panettone, on the other hand, is the gentleman’s choice because it’s so rich and smells like heaven, there are flavours hidden in the bites, you can find the raisin and then a piece of candied orange in the next one, or both, and the same goes for other flavours, also the glaze or “topping”
some style of panettone have makes sure that you won’t get bored at all while eating the slice, and the airy interior makes up for a moist and soft experience.

In other words, pandoro is for kids who loves simpler things, panettone is for grown ups.

>>18731581
>We shouldn't mess with the classic panettone – the idea that everything has to be new saddens me
>Panettone has been ruined by poor variations including prosecco, salted caramel, and savoury cheese flavours

>There are two things about the wave of adulterated panettones – featuring novelty flavours including everything from tiramisu to peach bellini and even parmesan and black pepper – that I strongly resent. The classic recipe and its original ingredients – flour, butter, raisins and candied citrus among them – were intended to make the cake last for some time. It was created to transport easily and takes days to make, for the dough to prove, but can last for weeks. It is pure.

>Modern technology, which enables producers to pump just about anything into panettone, has led to an ill-formed cake with an ingredients list packed with additives that are far from conducive to your health.

>Secondly, the idea that everything has to be new, or reinvented with new flavours, saddens me. Of course food – and our attitude towards it – changes through the ages, but just sometimes in life we ought to just stop and enjoy something that has been around for centuries. If something still excites our senses and makes our heart sing after so long, we ought to ask the question why.

>Panettone has been a Christmas tradition my whole life. We didn’t have much money when I was growing up and we didn’t have an oven capable of making one, but we would buy one – it was our treat, a Christmas cake only sold at Christmas time. I loved the airy texture, the generous amount of raisins and chunks of candied peel studded throughout, and would happily pick off the sugar crystals from the top to eat, to the annoyance of my mother. She insisted there had to be enough left for everyone to enjoy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18731591
>Its flavours were perfect. These days, they have been amplified so much they taste plastified, far too sugary. It deflects from what a great panettone should taste like. I’ve even made them myself over the years, none of them terribly successful as this is a hard cake to make – just look at that dough, its lightness, the glorious holes. Even more reason to respect the skill and specialist equipment of its traditional expert bakers.

>Consider panettone like you would a beautiful sourdough loaf – you wouldn’t want to change anything about such a brilliant bread. With loaves – and with panettone – if you change just a few ingredients the result will not stand the test of time.

>By all means toast slices of panettone and spread them with butter or jam, or turn them into a pudding topped with custard or (my favourite) molten chocolate. But prosecco panettone, salted caramel, savoury cheese versions? These one-hit wonders will never rival the real deal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

OK anons for real... listen...
SPICE JARS ARE NOT GREAT. There. I said it.
They are rigid and have internal airspace in which flavor escapes every time you open the bottle (process called "burping" the bottle, search on it if you wish).

The best way is airtight bags/foil, rolled up and clamped closed with a pin or clip. Almost like coke powder baggie style. The point is you want to squeeze out the airspace.

posts.com:
>>18731754
>It's those billboards
There's an interesting story about that, actually.
As I understand it, back in 2000 there was legislation to try and limit the number of new billboards that could be built on the highways and interstates.
"New" being the operative word. Advertisers fought back by pre-emptively erecting a bunch of new billboards in hopes they'd get grandfathered in.

But after that, the bill failed and their would-be monopoly crumbled. There was a massive surplus with low demand, so advertising costs plummeted to pennies in the more rural areas of the state.

That's why you see cases where a church or a liquor store manages to buy 6 in a row. They're literally Bargain Bin Billboards.

>>18704249
I don't know of any chinese ground tea that's similar in quality to good matcha. It probably exists but I'd bet its in such small batches it's not worth seeking out. Japanese are more hyperfixated on doing things a certain way than the Chinese.

>for Chinese tea do you need those small 80ml cups?
Do you mean a gaiwan or the actual drinking cup?
You can drink tea out of whatever you like, though more neutral material like porcelain or glass is better. The idea of drinking out of a small cup is to influence the mouth feel and cool it down quicker so you can drink it faster and taste more. Certain cups exist to increase aroma, some focus more on cooling faster, really if you ever get into wanting a kind of cup it'll mostly be for aesthetics. Very few people really get several kinds of cups for different occasions, some people into tasting get smelling cups. I do find myself enjoying the flavor more out of my porcelain 60 ml cups more than my antique western style 6 oz teacups, but I use the 6 oz cup more because I don't have to use a gong dao bei.
>Impossible to make amounts like I'm used to with western teas if I want to go for quality?
eh, I typically get a bit more tea liquor out of gong fu brewing overall than if I used the same amount of leaf to brew western style. But at once? Yeah you're going to get less, but brew times are faster. I guess its more an active effort to taste tea than just western style drinking. I still mostly brew red tea in western style because the quality increase in gong fu is negligible unless I'm really in the mood for trying to find different notes.
Japanese tea is the annoying one. you only get 3, maybe 4, extractions and it's a higher leaf to water ratio than chinese, so it ends up costing more money for less tea. But japanese green tea is stupidly harsh on the stomach anyways so maybe its for the best it's harder to drink a liter of it.

i only use 100ml gaiwans and 120ml for some teas, 200ml is huge imo. i then i drink from a 50ml cup and generally i drink around 1.5L per gongfu session and using 5-7g of tea, its still a bit more than 3-4g of tea for the same amount western brewed but i think its worth it, i usually grandpa brew instead of western brewing if i want a lot of tea though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18704336
Chinese tea culture is hyper casual so there's not really anything nearly as classy as a 4 hour long tea ceremony. Puerh is probably more or less the fancy stuff with the teapots designed around it and the culture of gifting it to your boss and such. But you still drink it with the same technique as anything else. I wouldn't put it even near the same category of flavors that matcha presents though, its just a completely different flavor profile and honestly its not very beginner friendly.
Chinese green teas have a different flavor overall from Japanese green teas, and that comes mostly from 2 factors; different cultivars and different processing. You can get into soil conditions as well but the other two are a bigger influence. Japanese have different tea tree cultivars that they'd bread for the qualities they want, chinese have their tea trees for the qualities they want. Japanese process via steaming and mostly do machine processing which cuts up the leaf more and increases surface area, Chinese process via dry heat and more by hand (due to cheap labor) so the leaf is more whole and has a different flavor profile. If you took a high quality Shincha and good Longjing, not even the most novice tea drinker could confuse them despite being both the most coveted highest quality greens in their respective countries. One is grassier with seaweed notes, one is tastes like roasted nuts.
Chinese and Japanese tea tastes don't overlap very much, and you can see that by what they drink. 90% of Japanese tea is green tea, Chinese is varied with Oolong probably having a slight edge.
Speaking of Oolong, it's probably going to be the best in class and taste without having to break into Puerh (though it's not the same flavor either). Oolong is somewhat fancy, given as gifts and growers have some pride in it, takes some technical skill to manufacture consistently. It can get rather pricey as well, but the mid shelf stuff at like $0.20 to $0.50 a gram is really good

>100 grams (about 4 ozs.) of Yerba Mate brewed with one liter of water have approximately the following:
>Potassium: 681.85 mg
>Magnesium: 167.60 mg
>Phosphorus: 93.00 mg
>Vitamin C: 2.55 mg
>Niacin: 12.98 mg
https://www.foodrelated.com/health-benefits-of-yerba-mate.html

84mg per 50g yerba used. Definitely a noticeable amount. But not significant to reach the recommended 400mg DV as say toss n washing epsom salt

>>18704249
Whipped tea actually originated in China but unfortunately the culture was wiped out during the Mongolian invasion and leaf culture was dominant by the time of the Ming Dynasty. Whipped tea only survived in Japan.
In Chinese tea ceremony, which is not of course as highly formalized, any high grade tea will do, usually high priced oolong like da hong pao. In Yunan it is customary to serve guests puer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tasting notes:
2014 Jinggu Raw Puerh from LP (got in beginner pack)
probably the same thing as this but not barrel stored
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1097193078/2014-jinggu-raw-puerh-rye-barrel-stored

Parameters:
11g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Appearance: whole reddish brown leaves, medium size, moderate/dry storage, orange Liquor.

Notes:
Savory, grilled squash
Some smokiness
Herbaceous, old straw and hay
Tart, crab apple
Slight mineral aftertaste
Moderate bitterness and astringency, robust but not over powering.

Conclusion:
Reminds me a bit of a more refined higher quality semi aged XG toucha. It has got a similar robust smoky energy to it but the higher quality non-cut leaves (compared to cheap XG productions) means it is less likely to over brew into an acrid mess. If this were still for sale I would have recommend it as a good example of robust semi aged sheng.

as a side not LP just dropped some cheap semi-aged cakes if anyone is looking.
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1358917496/2015-naka-357g
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1358905944/201011-ziyunhao-xiaguan-357g
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1027588512/2012-xiaguan-7543-357g

not semi-aged but the cake of this I bought last year was really good
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1010745017/2022-the-blister-exist-200g

>>18709854
I'm guessing he means that he is selling them very close to cost and is not making much on them. I.E. not taking his business seriously. Would be nice if he gave a proper description but I can't complain too much at the price. It is a wet stored standard XG production so I have a pretty good idea what it likely tastes like.

For reference KTM sells the same cake (but different storage) for $11 more before shipping.
https://kingteamall.com/collections/2012-xiaguan/products/2012-xiaguan-7543-iron-cake-357g-puerh-sheng-cha-raw-tea
grandnesstea sells a (presumably dry stored) version for $39
https://www.grandnesstea.com/7543-2012-Xiaguan-Ancient-Tree-Pu-erh-Tea-Cake-Puer-Puerh-Tea-Raw-Sheng-357g-p92047.html
The cake probably sells for cheaper on taobao but after using a forwarding agent and paying for shipping you probably won't save much if anything.

Lp's cheaper cakes tend to be good deals if you live in the US and factor in shipping. That is a big part of the reason I mention them. Plus they won't take two months to get to you. The downside is that his selection is small and always changing so he does not always have cheap cakes in stock (they tend to sell out the fastest).

I'm using a 100ml gaiwan, boiling water. Started with a quick rinse then a ~20s first infusion, increased time with further infusions but wasn't tracking the time very precisely. First time I did 7 infusions and the second time I stopped at 3.
I'm terrible at at describing taste but I feel it kind of reminded me of the aftertaste of chocolate milk, and it was very smooth, which isn't what I usually expect out of tea.

It can take a while for me to learn to enjoy things, so I haven't entirely given up on it. I'll give it another gongfu attempt before trying grampa. If everything fails I'll try again in half a year when it's winter in the southern hemisphere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18723915
Sounds like you are brewing it the way i would, your description of the taste sounds about right.
I guese you can try using more tea and or pushing the steeps longer and see if you enjoy it with a more concentrated brew.
Also the grampa style i suggested. It will really hit its stride and give the most favor on the first refil so try and make it that far.
You can also try simmering it. 6.5 grams in 1.25 litres of water, low simmer for 15-20 minutes. That will also give you a very different flavor profile.
You also just might not like ripe, that's fine its not for everyone. Keep the cake around and try it again after 6 months or a year and see if your opinion changes at all.

posts.com: what's the best way to remove limescale from an electric kettle I'm gonna be using for tea?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18730143
a decent way is to put 1-2 tablespoons of citric acid into a full kettle, the boil it and let it sit for a bit like 30 minutes. if theres still buildup after rinsing you can repeat it.
you can also use white vinegar with basically the same method, 50/50 water/vinegar

Was curious if tea lesbians are just a /tea/ meme like some anons have said before and I found an academic paper from 2015. This is the very beginning
> In Go Fish, Rose Troche and Guinevere Turner's seminal lesbian film from 1994, one of the protagonists complains that the woman who her friends want to set her up with has cupboards of herbal tea and no sex appeal. In the course of the film, the women end up together, but the joke/not-joke about lesbians and their fondness for herbal tea remains. What can we make of this conjunction? What does the linkage of tea and lesbianism connote and how does tea function within representational economies of lesbianism? On the one hand, tea functions as prelude to eroticism and codes for the opacity of lesbian sex. On the other hand, it also works to consolidate stereotypes about lesbianism. In this essay, the author explores the factors that make this almost joke possible – the gendering of tea as feminine, stereotypes about lesbian feminism – and examine ways in which it has been deployed as a form of lesbian shorthand

>>18732137
Depends, but cook skill is more important. There is a skill floor that MUST be passed for the food to be safe to eat, and there is a quality floor that MUST be passed for the food to be safe to eat. Fortunately the FDA and other authorities abroad help the common man with the latter, but is not a guaranteed thing. People still get food poisoning, and you can do it to yourself if you aren't smart enough.

So once both conditions are satisfied, the skill off the chef matters more. Burnt food, overcooked items, too dry, too wet, raw, all potential fuckups that can happen by a chef. A great chef even knows methods for using cheap stuff better. Plus ingredients don't cook themselves, and chefs add to visual elements that enhance the meal.

Even ingredients depend on the skill of their handler. Kobe beef isn't born in the wild, it is from expert humans doing weird shit to cows to make it super marbled and taste. The same applies to plants: they were shit originally, then humans fucked with them to make them better via breeding and now genetic modification.

my chili recipe
browned ground beef with onions or onion flakes
kidney beans
canned tomatoes
mushrooms (pieces and stems)
chili powder
cumin
salt
pepper
paprika
onion flakes
garlic powder
rice (cooked separately)

brown ground beef in a pan and either chop up onions or throw onion flakes in it, and season with salt and pepper while cooking. drain excess fat from the ground beef.

toss the ground beef and everything else except the rice in a crock pot. add water if the tomatoes don't have enough liquid. stir it all up and cook on low for 8 hours. then lower it to warm and let sit while making the rice in a rice cooker. when the rice is done scoop out some rice and scoop chili over the rice. enjoy.

>Reintroduce enough bacon grease to bottom of rondeau and brown beef scraps and ground beef in bacon grease
>In a separate large pot, brown peppers and onions in tallow or bacon grease then introduce minced garlic. Deglaze with beer and then add browned beef, parcooked bacon, any leftover bacon grease, chili paste, and chili seasoning
>Let seasoning/paste cook into meat for 20 mins
>Add fire roasted tomato and rest of beer, bring to simmer and let reduce for 1 hour
>Turn off heat, stir in salt, then season to taste

3/3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are two ways.
A. Procedural
Start with dried BEANS, canned ones have already been cooked at far too high a heat and will turn to shit. I recommend pressure cooking your own rehydrated beans, this is also far cheaper.

Ground beef often has too much fat to sear, don't be scared to pour that fat off then add it back in with the onions.

Use whole spice, fry the whole spice off in vegetable oil, then either blend the mixture or just use the oil. This is unfamiliar to Americans but Indians and Chinese understand you get more value and fresher spices. Again add this with the onions and you speed up the cooking time.

Add the beans after the onions are done, this avoids over cooking your beans.

Add stock rather than water.
I boil beef bones then ladle the stock in as the chili reduces so it's not dry. This adds nutrition and means you can use less ground beef.

B. Ingredients
Whole spice is always preferable.
Don't buy meat which was butchered 5 days ago then pumped full of water, or mince that's half fat, the fat will merely stop you getting a good sear and float to the top as an oil slick.

When it comes to tomatoes make sure you're buying sauce tomatoes to make sauce. You may find passata is a better option, only use tomato paste if you can't get sauce tomatoes or is significantly cheaper.

Cinnamon lifts a chili up, so does bay leaf. Go easy on the garlic.

Remember onions are for flavor, huge flavorless onions make a sweet, flavorless chili. All things being equal buy shallottes, there's nothing wrong with wild onions or a mix of different onions.

Don't chili corn. It's shit and if you really want corn add it when serving otherwise again you're just boiling the sugar out of it.

>inb4 buthurt about not using a single pot
>inb4 buthurt from Texan autists

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18727150
>beans
>rice
That's not chili.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also the same rules for hard spice apply to chili. Use fresh chili with onions, failing that blend whole dried chillies (don't fry them off just drop them into the hot oil before blending) failing that chili flakes. There is no excuse for using chili powder.

Never add pre made hot sauce. You're cooking, remember? Don't add table condiments as ingredients.
Don't cook with cheese, cheese is best added when serving. Cheese is expensive and boiling the dairy fats out of it only adds to the oil slick.

Rice never goes in a chili, you serve rice as a side. Cooking it creates a clag of starch and makes reheating a pain and freezing a waste.
If you want to make chili as if it was a Spanish Paella you would have to cook the whole thing like a paella and at that point.

It's totally acceptable to cook chili in a clay pot/tangine/ Dutch oven. This works well if your using rehydrated beans but not preassure cooking. If you're using whole beefs like a mole it's actually the best way.

Some people prefer a lighter chili with chicken stock, white beans, or chicken. In this case see: cassoulette, French one pot chicken with beans.
Cooking this like a chili will just string out your chicken.
>unami bombing
Cheese, soya sauce, stock powder, excessive tomato paste, fish sauce etc.
What you crave is MSG and you may as well add it pure and avoid polluting your chili further. If this is you then remember MSG is instantly soluble and to reduce salt by 1/3.

If you cook raw beans in tomato sauce the acid fucks with them, some people prefer this but if you're not happy with the texture of your beans try boiling them separately, discarding the liquid, adding them later. Or preassure cook.

Never add salt, msg, or any other soluble mineral prior to reducing. It shits me to tears how many people don't know this and how many chefs persist in this. It's not a matter of purism nor is it pedantic. You either are overstalting all your sauce, risk doing so for no reason.

>Why do you need vinegar etc if you can just sterilize the stuff?
Acidic foods don't need to reach the same temperature as foods canned in plain water. You can can pickled beets in a water bath; if you want to can fresh beets in water, you need a pressure canner. Also, pickles.
>Also, why do these say 'not for canning' on them?
I don't know I don't make them. The description mentions low levels of water and "dry steam" which is not how a canner operates. They're twice as expensive as the canners from the same brand anyways, just get a canner.

Bruno revised his eclair recipe not too long ago:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LT7MIfTzNhM
I found it interesting that he pipes them in long 19" strips and freezes them before cutting them to size instead of piping each individually. They still bake up with round edges like you expect with the class method, but it seems faster and less fussy.

For the crème pâtissière filling a found a pretty good dedicated video for it that recommends passing the custard through a sieve both after tempering the eggs with the hot diary and again after final thickening on the stove and then processing it in a blender for smoothness and to emulsify in a tablespoon or two of butter/melted chocolate/etc in fully.

>>18730957
No, but she should do that anyway with the kenmore, it is recommended in the manual and makes sense. I usually would have hot water running anyway since I use it in the scrape food off phase.
The dishwasher pod problem is that dishwashers have a prewash and a main wash and drain the water out in between. So if you use a single detergent pod you only have soap in one of the cycles. Solution is to either use two pods (one in main wash compartment and one just tossed in the bottom at start) or go back to powder. I do powder.
The kenmore smart cycle seems to work well. It has a sensor that checks how gross the water is to determine how long it should run. There are other cycles that should be used with care like Turbo because it uses a different set of horizontal jets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1:23, happy holidays you fu/ck/s. I just threw together the best holiday impromptu drink I've ever had.

Spritz of DiSaronno amaretto, maybe half a shot
The residual juice off a lemon I used for cooking a few minutes earlier
A toothpaste glob of honey
A small packet size of butter, stirred until it's dissolved
An equal shot of warm Earl Grey tea

I call it Holiday Brine, and it's perfect for sipping, I'd imagine it would also be a wonderful cooking brine and that any meat marinaded with this would be amazing. Keep in mind DiSaronno has a sweet, maraschino cherry syrup like flavor to it, and this particular brand has been made since 1525 - I don't know if other amarettos are as good but this is the only one I can recommend. I'm thinking of simmering some with sugar, into a syrup, and having pancakes topped with it for breakfast in a few hours. Cheers!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: By the way, I forgot to mention that this tastes just like Christmas Punch - if you're thinking of spending all day boiling fruit stock, just buy a bottle of DiSaronno and make tea instead

As others say, if you return to the same restaurant after not tipping, you may get shitty service (possibly literally... like if the cook is pissed off at the world and feels like sticking a poopfinger in someone's food, it's going to be yours).

Basically, if you're eating out at an American sit-down restaurant, then you consider the expected minimum 15% tip as an extra tax, like state/local sales tax. You only leave less than 15% if the service was really bad and you want to send a message (in which case you probably have no intention of returning anyway). Sometimes people leave more than 15% if the service was exceptional, or they are feeling generous, or they are trying to impress a date, or (most often) they are embarrassingly trying to flirt with the waitress.

Some restaurants have the credit card machines the default to an 18% or even 20% minimum tip and require a bunch of extra taps to enter less, trying to make you look like as asshole. Don't patronize those places.

Personally I would prefer a tipless society (like in many other countries), but it's not really a big problem, because who's eating out that often at sit-down restaurants anyway?

The main domestic objections to tipping come from autistic manchildren who can't into social convention; they "reeeee" about any practice without black & white rules (requiring human empathy to interpret). The waitress serving your microwaved tendies isn't getting rich from that extra 15%, it's just allowing the restaurant owner to avoid paying her minimum wage, and yeah that sucks, but if you don't like it, microwave your own tendies like a grown manchild.

posts.com:
yeah OP this shit sucks. the "until done" shit persists in a lot of recipes largely because explaining what that means takes a lot of words, and once you've been cooking for a while you learn by sense what it means. a lot of recipes also do a bad job emphasizing the purpose of each step which leads to newfriends not really understanding why they're doing certain things.

i really recommend following recipes from food youtubers for a while so you can see what the food looks like at each step. they have to pad video length for ads, so they also do a better job of explaining what they're going for in each step. chef john (food wishes) and babish are pretty good for this when you know absolutely nothing. babish kinda just adopts all his recipes from chef john, america's test kitchen, and j kenji lopez, but because he's fairly inexperienced himself he emphasizes the kind of stuff you need to look out for at your expertise level (retard)

stovetop burners all cook at different heats, the numbers are only relative to your stove. you're just going to have to learn the minute differences between your stove and others' generally. everything in the kitchen is approximate, so you're just gonna have to use the cook times as a rough guideline and learn to spot that "until done" stuff we talked about above. you can only really figure it out by cooking a bunch

sorry but you are just kinda retarded for the cups thing bro. get a measuring cup or something. i have a bunch of little cups/containers that are exactly 1 cup that use to quickly scoop out whatever i need in that quantity and eyeball half/three-quarters/etc.

cook some easy recipes like minestrone, mac and cheese, and pasta sauce and you'll figure some stuff out. it's easier than it seems, you just need to build the knowledge of how food changes through the process of cooking.

>>18731213
Here's the dirty little secret about cooking : It is not an exact science.
Except for baked goods or very specific things like roux, you're not gonna ruin a dish by using 20% more or less of any given ingredient called for in a recipe. Going for the exact measurement down to the gram or the milliliter is absolutely not necessary, it's just a useful approximation of what you should try to aim for, which is helpful for novices who never cooked anything in their whole lives and are too inexperienced to know they shouldn't put 10 tablespoons of cayenne pepper in their stew.
At the end of the day, using 200ml of tomato paste instead of 250ml isn't gonna turn a delicious dish into something inedible. Cooking something on medium instead of medium-low isn't gonna incinerate whatever's in your pan, etc.
Plus, not following exact instruction gives you the flexibility to tweak the dish to your own tastes. For exemple, whenever a recipe calls for a 1/1/1 or 1/1/2 ratio of celery/carrots/onions, I always do 1/2/3 instead because that's how I like my mirepoix.
Cooking should be an enjoyable, zen experience. No need to turn the process into some sort of autistic hard science. It's not necessary, and you'll end up with tasty food either way.

I almost burned a patron with a hot tray some years ago.
The locale I worked in didn't have a proper corridor to send baked products to the entrance counter, so we had to walk all the way from the work area to there to bring the products, going through the restaurant tables.
It was a busy day and I was carrying some small breads on a tray I just took out of the oven because someone had already paid for them and was waiting at the counter. Being the little cocky shit I was I carried the tray on one hand, only using one mitten to carry it open handed; I had done it before, I was in a hurry and the tray didn't weigh a lot.

posts.com:
posted on /v/ by mistake earlier.

Today I experimented with adding bread crumbs to the ground beef for my tacos. It was a complete success. The taco meat was tender, moist, and flavorful. I surmised that the bread crumbs would prevent the ground beef from essentially bonding together into a rubbery mass as they cooked. The texture is more akin to what you'd get at a fast food place, something that I am looking for in a taco meat.
Instead of browning the meat in the pan first and then adding the taco powder like the instructions say, I mixed ground beef, taco powder, bread crumbs, and a beef cube in a mixing bowl and then added them to a pan that already had some translucently cooked chopped up onions in the pan.

More pics to follow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18721888
>I'm going to cook a prime rib dinner for my family on christmas, what are some good sides to go with it?
Took advantage of the Publix prices last 2 years in a row and got a 4rib portion.
Think British, really.
Get a nice trifle bowl and your trifle laced with sherry soaking, macerating the berries and boozy, get it good and cold. This is your dessert of choice.
For nice apps, anything seafood is popular, from an old fashioned cold shrimp cocktail to some stone crabs. For sides, you want a seasonal soup course, or a nice salad course, your pick Gorgonzola on that salad or cheese tray. It's pretty chilly this year, so the steakhouse soups are okay, like french onion. Remember you will want some horseradish w/ sourcream, lemon and parsley to make it special.
I like a good pan gravy which is going to happen with coffee in the pan and a covered roaster, so will want mashed potatoes with that roast beef gravy (versus roasted). Fancymode, twice bake some big potatoes. Bake up your tray of veggies from mushrooms to winter squash, brussels sprouts, mix em! or like tomato halves with herbs and breadcrumbs. A casserole like creamed baby onions or creamed spinach to add another side. If your oven is crowded, you rest that roast under foil, and reheat the gravy, that's all. Use your burner to steam some green beans w/red onions.
Pro-mode is yorkshire pudding. I am a sucker for nice rolls too.
MUST HAVE, a nice raspberry jello mold with cranberries and oranges. Or some kind of grandma style picalilli. It just goes to balance your plate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
red potatoes
wash and scrub
cut into 8ths, 12ths, 16ths, or 20ths depending on size
put into large mixing bowl
add olive oil, salt, pepper, garlic powder, optionally paprika
Toss to evenly coat
dump out onto foiled oven tray
bake in oven at like 400f for like 40m

You can try this in smaller batches to figure out your spice ratio preferences. I typically use only a little salt, a a good amount of garlic powder, and enough pepper that my family tells me to make them with less pepper.

>>18730694
I'm from Italy, but my uncle married a Nihonjin woman from (... I wanna say Kobe?) who, in the 80s, had few options for actual Japanese ingredients so had to create Japitalian fusion (since she didn't know how to cook Italian food and my uncle only knew how to cook fish) and it was good stuff.
Most other naturally occuring fusion cuisines I've had have also been good, such as Peranakan cooking, Burgher cooking, American Chinese cooking, AngloIndian cooking, ItaloEcuadorian cooking, TexMex/American Southwestern cooking and so on. The only one I can say I've disliked is ItaloAmerican/ItaloAustralian cooking, but that's likely due to my own cultural chauvinism.
If you've ever had and liked masala chai, congratulations; you've enjoyed something that was the product of naturally occuring fusion cuisine.
Fusion can be good, but not when made through a hamfisted attempt to shoehorn things together that simply don't work.

annyeong
Korean (hangul.. aka written letters) is written clockwise. So..안 =... the ㅇis a place holder(like silent letter in English)..ㅏ="Ah"+ㄴ="n"... so together "an" 녕...ㄴ="n" , ㅕ="yeo" and ㅇ when below is "ng"... so all together "annyeong" or "Hello"
t. Korean wife haver...
Learned Hangul in like 2 days... Its same English alphabet. I memorized ㅏlooks like A, ㅓlooks like E "eo", ㅜ looks like U,ㅗ sorta looks like O. For more letters ez.. ㅑis "A with a Y" or "Ya",ㅕ add Y to "eo" for "yeo",ㅠ was "u" now "yu" and ㅛ was "0" and now is "yo". Now you know 8 very common letters in Korean.

>>18731261
>you should always have at least oats, peanut butter/nuts/seeds, and fruit
This. I always have iced coffee in the can, pallets of water and juice from costco, several flavors of granola bars, PB, unopened jellies in the pantry.
Tuna, onion, celery is salad. Yea, sometimes you do run low on bread, but with the winter storm the entire country is facing, you gotta stock up ahead. There used to be a bread-o-meter on the weather reports in DC. Cheesy graphic to know how many loaves of bread you needed to have for # of days expected to be snowed in.

I live in Hurricane territory, and there are some staples to keep around. A can of drained beans, chopped celery, vinegar/citrus juice, herbs, onion. This kind of thing makes a nice bean dip for crackers. Slice an avocado for same. If expected to go out, you bring your ice blocks into an ice chest and move your salami and cheese to the cooler. Bagels and cream cheese. Move your eggs, and breakfasty things for outside cooking. For the BBQ grill, own a coffee pot that grills nicely, like an old percolator.

Here's mine OP, inb4 I get mogged for putting corn in my chili.

INGREDIENTS:

FRESH
5-6lb of ground beef
1 ½ large onions
4 large bell peppers

CANNED
3 28oz cans of whole peeled San Marzano tomatoes
2 14oz cans of dark red kidney beans
1 14oz can of whole kernel corn
1 7oz can of chipotle peppers

WET INGREDIENTS
2 tbsp of honey
1 tbsp mustard
2 tsp Worcestershire
2 tsp soy sauce
2 tsp fish sauce
fat/oil for frying

SPICES
5 tbsps. chili powder
Habanero/cayenne powder
1 tbsp paprika
1 tbsp cumin
1 tbsp Chicken Bullion
½ tsp garlic powder

OPTIONAL GARNISHES
Sour cream
Crackers, corn chips, tortilla chips
Avocado
Chives or parsley
Shredded Cheese


Also why yes the chicken bullion I use is indeed Knorr™ brand

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18733034
As someone who lived and cooked in Japan, I can tell you that JustOneCookbook is the definitive English blog for Japanese recipes and cooking. Her youtube videos are often very succinct too which is nice.

Many techniques are transferable but they are all pretty different cuisines so learning one may not help you too much with another. For example, they all wash their rice, they all make fried rice differently.

The best thing is to just look for food/dishes and try to make them. Look up a few recipes, compare what they all have in common, and what's different about them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

>>18713841
bad hummus...
was camping with friends and had cooked a big celebration dinner for something--Steaks, hobo pack veggies and baked potatoes on the campfire...all fresh and from scratch except for 1 thing--some hummus that LOOKED and TASTED ok, maybe a little sour, but not really OFF.
Just as we'd finished cleaning up,(quickly, as a big summer storm was rolling in,) the storm hit with a vengence--big fucking banger of a thunderstorm too.
laying down in my tent with the driving rain pelting the fly, All of a sudden, I got that feeling--you know, the tight, almost battery acid tasting tightness right behind your jaw? I knew I had seconds to get out for the inevitable technicolor yawn...
Wouldn't you know? the fucking zipper gets stuck, off track, a good 3-5 minutes of fucking around with it in the best of circumstances--and that rain is fucking coming down in BUCKETS.
PANIC....Sheer panic sets in, I can't hold my gorge back any longer...
I fucking ripped the tent door open at the zipper and stumbled out into the now hammering rain, puking all that excellent dinner we'd just eaten in all directions as I staggered through the muddy forest to get further away from the tent, so I didn't have a pool of vomit sitting right outside of it. I spent the next 15 minutes on all fours, purging my entire being until I could do nothing but dry heave with sheets of water coming down all around me...
I was fine in the morning, and was able to fix the tent zipper so that it would NEVER LOCK UP ON ME AGAIN...but that had to be the worst.
Only one almost as bad was burning through half a case of little kings playing the "minute game"I made good friends with the snails that night as I crawled around in the dewy grass under the full moon...good times.
btw, when I checked that Godforsaken CURSED HUMMUS the next morning, it was actually bubbling--so I know that was the culprit.
I still like hummus though, even if I always give it the hairy-eyeball if it's store-bought.

It can be disconcerting to visit a fast food restaurant and feel like the atmosphere is lacking in some way. It's worth noting that fast food restaurants are designed to be efficient and quick, rather than cozy or atmospheric. This means that they often have a more utilitarian decor and may not have the same level of ambiance as a sit-down restaurant. However, every location is different, and it's possible that the Taco Bell you visited just happened to have a particularly soulless atmosphere.

>>18732521
You should try using a rice cooker with exact instructions, letting the rice soak for 30 minutes before cooking, and letting it sit for 20 minutes after it's done without opening it. Also the type of rice matters, short grain Asian rice is supposed to be sticky. Long grain rice like basmati will work better. You can also try using a little oil on the washed rice, making sure each grain is individually coated, but this works better if you're going to cook it in stock or other flavors.

Get a heavy bottom pan and use avocado oil or ghee. Super high smoke point oils are best. Thick cuts of steak work best.

>>18728852
1. As others said, egg whites and a bit of baking soda help
2. Don't let your mince get too warm prior to forming.
3. If using shredded onions or other veggies with high water content, wring them extremely well to get the water out, as this will otherwise fight the adhesion of the fats to the skewer and itself
4. If you are using a very wide skewer (think koobideh) ensure enough meat coverage on the side edges and don't hesitate to turn them VERY frequently at the start, as otherwise they can slough off the skewer. After a couple minutes they'll be more solid

I've eaten at a 2 star and 3 star place. I thought the 2 star was overall better since it included a stay in the hotel and truly luxury experience. Here were the highlights:

>picked you up from the airport in a luxury car
>asked what sort of bedding you preferred before your arrival
>room came with fresh fruit, wine, nuts, bottled water, and you could take any of the books or things you liked with you.
>drinks and amuse bouche in the garden
>7 or 8 course menu with wine pairings
>drinks and coffee after in the study
>they shined my shoes before dinner since they had been scuffed up
>they organized private activities that were actually really reasonable to partake in. Classic car rentals, fishing excursions, falconry in the orchard, etc.
>and of course it was easily some of the best food I've ever had.

All in for a night's stay, the meal, the drinks, the activities, and an hour ride from the airport it was $1200 a person. Seemed pretty reasonable all things considered. Probably won't do stuff like that too often, but it was a fantastic experience.

posts.com:
I've been to quite a few Michelin star restaurants but can't always remember their names, DESU.

Some of the ones I remember:

Le Bernadin (NYC) - ***
Daniel (NYC) - **
Gabriel Kreuther (NYC) - **
Aquavit (NYC) - **
Jean Georges (NYC) - **
Gramercy Tavern (NYC) - *
Blue Hill (NYC) - *
The River Cafe (NYC) - *
Le Saint James (Bordeaux) - *
Le Gavroche (London) - **
Kitchen W8 (London) - *
Portland (London) - *
HIDE (London) - *
Brasserie Zedel (London) - *
Hakkasan (London) - *
Galvin La Chapelle (London) - *
Jose (London) - *

I dread to think how much money that adds up to. Most of these were dates with my wife but there is the occasional business meeting in there.

Now that I have kids, we very rarely go out to Michelin star restaurants as it is hard to justify the consooming. The most recent was Gabriel Kreuther before seeing a play on Broadway (Leopoldstadt).

My overall view is that *** and ** places can be overpriced and a bit soulless at times (but not always). I'm not really interested in all the bullshit food theatre you can get at some of those places. There can also be a typical consoomerist fight to secure a reservation, which is really just quite tedious.

Nowadays I tend to prefer * restaurants as they are often more low key (and better value).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Put 3 eggs in bowl and scramble with fork
2. Add pinch of salt and grind some black pepper in
3. Melt a little butter in a non-stick pan and lower it to low heat once melted
4. Add eggs and stir with long slow strokes to keep the curds long
5. Turn off the heat when the eggs just start to come together, the eggs cook themselves at that point
6. Serve on toast with chives if you have any

Easy, no gimmick ingredients, just eggs. Just cook low and slow and take it off before it's cooked how you like it.

Poblano, Guajillo, Arbol peppers toasted, rehydrated and processed. Reserve

Sear your meat, preferably chuck filet. minced meat added up to you. Reserve
Render fat from bacon. Reserve
Cook onion in fat
Add fresh Serrano, Anaheim, red bell pepper + whatever other peppers you want
Add tomato paste, caramelize
Chili powder, oregano or thyme, cumin. Add cayenne for extra heat or chipotle for smokiness. Toast
Add back your meat inc. bacon
Pour in chili sauce
Beef stock
Can of whole tomatoes, break up and add
Mix together
If you wanted to add beans put it in now, up to you
Let simmer for 2-3 hours
Add beer to chili + dark chocolate
adjust seasoning to taste
Garnish with sour cream and cheese

Enjoy cunt

>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

>ordering no salt fries at mcdicks to "force them to make a fresh batch"
I hate this "lifehack" with an undying fucking passion. I am convinced people doing this is 100% to blame for fast food restaurants never salting their fries appropriately any more. Instead of getting nice salty fries with salt melted right into the oil as it dries on the surface of the fries you get bland saltless fries that you have to try to add salt to when they're already dry and cool, it doesn't taste the same. On the plus side, this phenomenon has reduced my consumption of fast food in general, but I wish I could still get a nice well-salted order of fries now and again and I blame those retarded lifehack fucks for permanently ruining it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18728718
In many European countries, it is common for beer to be sold at room temperature in grocery stores and other retail outlets. This is because beer is often stored and transported at room temperature before it is sold, and it is not necessary to refrigerate it in order to preserve its quality. There are several reasons why beer is traditionally sold at room temperature in Europe. One reason is that beer is often sold in small quantities, and refrigerating it would be inefficient. In addition, many European beers are designed to be served at cellar temperature, which is slightly cooler than room temperature. It is also worth noting that refrigeration technology has not always been widely available, and in some parts of Europe, it is still not as common as it is in other parts of the world. However, this is changing as refrigeration becomes more widespread, and it is now possible to find beer that is sold chilled in many European countries. In conclusion, the reason that you saw warm beer on the shelves in European grocery stores is likely due to the traditional way that beer is sold and consumed in these countries, as well as the availability of refrigeration.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18729221
Huge outlay in terms of infrastructure, very hard to roster staff across multiple sections.
Expecting FOH to be cafe trained, bar trained and do the lifting in bakery is a recipe for disaster.

I used to work in a place exactly like that and it went under. Opening for 12 hours every day fucked the front of house staff, they'd get in at 6 to set up the cafe bakery and if we didn't have enough staff then they would end up doing 11+ hour shifts, they made mistakes because they were exhausted, most walked off the job after a few months.

Bakeries don't use wood fired ovens, it's horribly inefficient. Wood fired pizza is also inefficient so your really limited in terms of take away.
Alcohol sales carried our dinner service and if we took too many take away orders it fucked the dine in pizza. People who come to pick up pizza are often app drivers who won't hang around and will refuse to carry your orders.

The Turks get this right by using a modern conveyor oven, selling all manner of flat bread, and keeping coffee service to a bare, bare minimum. If people want some oat milk frappe shit tell them to fuck off and go to Starbucks, you can't compete with places like starbucks

>>18730955
As someone who loves fast food, the McChicken is definitely one of my favorite sandwiches. There's just something about that crispy breaded chicken patty, topped with lettuce and mayonnaise, that hits the spot every time.

One of my favorite memories of eating a McChicken was when I went to my local McDonald's for lunch. As I was waiting in line to order, I struck up a conversation with the friendly worker behind the counter. We chatted about how busy the restaurant was that day and how much we both enjoyed working at McDonald's.

When it was finally my turn to order, I decided to go with my usual: a McChicken with a side of fries and a Coke. The worker asked if I wanted anything else, and I told her that the McChicken was all I needed. She smiled and told me that it was one of her favorite sandwiches too.

As I sat down to enjoy my meal, I couldn't help but feel grateful for the small but meaningful exchange I had with the McDonald's worker. It reminded me of the importance of simple acts of kindness and human connection, even in the midst of a busy day.

Overall, the McChicken is a delicious and satisfying fast food sandwich that always brings a smile to my face. Whether I'm eating it at a McDonald's or at home, it's a go-to meal that never disappoints. So, it's my favorite fast food sandwich.

posts.com:
I usually slow cook the stew then cook the rice separately afterwards.
The rice is better that way, you can't really make risotto in a multi cooker because it requires constant stirring- yes it absolutely will stick.

If you ever get burn in a non stick pan it's important not to scratch the pan.
Tip everything into another container leaving whatever sticks in the pot. scrape the burnt shit out/off with a wooden spoon, rinse the pot, put the good food back into it, add some water so it won't burn again

>>18729430
This shit happens to me when I try and make chili verde, it's because the sauce isn't thinned out enough, or is sitting on top. the instant pot required liquid at the bottom to create pressure, so if what you're cooking is too thick it'll trip the burn warning. I usually have to add anywhere from one to 2 additional cups of water or broth before its able to pressure cook.
Also, if it does thin out too much, just add a slurry of cornstarch to it after its finished to thicken back up.

posts.com:
>>18730739
From my experience, which has been cooking in cast iron for many many years, bacon will not stick if you keep your heat low enough, and let it render.

The problem comes when the heat gets too high, and it's not so much the meat that sticks, it's the sugar in the bacon that caramelizes and hardens, which causes it to stick. Using uncured bacon will mostly solve this, but keeping the heat low enough will prevent it

>>18730265
>>18730315
>It's not a type of pepper it's a method of preparation.
>They're (usually) smoked Filipinos.
At least in U.S. cuisine (and probably everywhere -- I don't believe your waffling) a chipotle is *always* a ripe jalapeno that is smoked and dried to different levels. Morita and meco are the two common types seen (and now that I think of it, morita are indeed sold everywhere in the U.S. there are dried chilies alongside ancho; others are hit-or-miss).
https://smallaxepeppers.com/what-is-a-chipotle-pepper/
I envy that your market has so many varieties on just the preparation and terroir? of the same varietals -- as long as the price is reasonable (which I'm guessing since it's an Asian market it generally is.) I live next to a Super88 in a major city and it's just got the common set of chilies -- all the varietals, but no variety. Same with the Latinx market in the middle of an enormous West Indies diaspora. I haven't been everywhere though, obviously.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18730435
Some moritas are wholly unripe, but mecos are always completely ripe (sometimes over) - it's why moritas are darker. And I have seen jalapeno-seco sold as chipotle - it's a nice flavour, but kind of odd when you're expecting smoke. The rainman makes sure to label them as both in three languages... often to the point where the tags completely hide the peppers in the bag.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18731172
I thought he might have been referring to my
>(usually) smoked
But yeah, nah, 0265 missed some details. They absolutely have to be jalapeno - other peppers can be prepared similarly (I usually smoke up some chilacas, poblanos, and habs when I've got enough ripe, half-ripe, or storebought jalapenos that are starting to sag), but only the smoked jalapenos are chipotles. Heavily smoked, super ripe ones are meco/moreno (because they turn brown), and everything else kind of falls under morita (because they're... mulberries? Get out of here Mexico, you're drunk again!), but I've seen the unripe ones called verde or negro. Moritas are ripe or half-ripe most of the time.

Getting off of this topic, I'd love to hit a cooking competition with mackerel - watch everyone else try to hide or mask the fishiness of it while I just work with it - finish er off with some god damned pavlova with saba mousse rosettes and white chocolate drizzled skin crackers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18723005
I like a moka every once in a while. how are you making it? I make it by: boiling water, pour it into the bottom, pour in the coffee, assemble the parts twist tight but not too tight, put on the burner for medium or medium-low-ish heat. Wait for the water to steam through and pour out the top. It should be a slow pour from the spout and not a violent bubbling. Some sputtering will occur, I've never gotten it not to occur (and if it doesn't it probably wasn't hot enough heat to produce a good taste coffee). Once its done pouring out, take off the heat and use hot hands to disassemble it and keep the top part on a small plate. Pour and enjoy.

I wouldn't say my coffee ever comes out "sour". It comes out as they espresso-like brew that mokas produce. Usually stronger in profile/flavor/etc than something like a V60 or drip machine. Sometimes it's even a little sweet tasting, in a way. Does that sound anything like how you make it? I think most people 1. don't boil their water before hand in a kettle and 2. use too high heat when it's on the burner

About a month back I was here asking for advice on picking a manual coffee grinder so I can grind beans for my moka pot. People here helped me pick the 1zpresso q2 as a starter grinder and I've been using it for the past couple of weeks. I'd like to say thanks. Someone even linked me the instructions on how to adjust it for a moka pot which I knew had to be a bit coarser than espresso. It did make a difference, I was able to fit a couple of grams of grounds less in the basket (when compared to to the espresso grounds I'd been using before).

And it might be my imagination but the flavor does seem to be better now. At the very least it's more consistent. Before, sometimes I'd get a cup that was too bitter or acidic, but now it's perfect every time. And using the grinder is next level satisfying, thanks for the help lads.

>he make Haribo joke...
I was given a copper V60-ish pourover a few years ago, something a friend made, and it does work great, but it comes with a few caveats (that I already knew from brewing beer)
1) You want to clean and dry that shit. Oxidized copper's ok, but copper salts are bad for piggy's digestion. If you start seeing verdigris (blue or green), scrub it off.
2. A warmup's not a terrible idea, but it's nowhere near as effective as it is on porcelain or glass, because the copper cools down (and also heats up) much faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18730248
I store my green coffee in very heavy gauge plastic grain bags at around 60ºF in the basement. I am very careful to remove all the air from the bags, and I seal them airtight. My green coffee lasts about 18 months before I notice flavor loss. I dip into the mothership bags to retrieve about 5lbs at a time. I'm less careful with storing the smaller bags because I use that up within a few months.

I store roasted coffee in regular 1qt Ziplock freezer bags in the kitchen cabinet at room temp (70-75ºF), squeezing the air out every time I open it. It stays fresh for about a month, but I almost always drink it within 2 weeks.

The important theme here is protection from oxygen, humidity, excessive heat, and UV light, all of which degrade coffee at all stages more quickly. The problem with mason jars is that you cannot easily remove the oxygen. They make coffee storage canisters with vacuum pumps, but I don't bother. You can suck the air out of plastic bags by sticking a straw into the corner and sucking if you really want to. You can also buy one-way valve bags, but those are more for selling roasted coffee. You'll have to heat seal them again every time once opened to be on the level of a plastic bag or a fancy vacuum canister.

Applying for disability puts you on a wait list for determination. This takes anywhere from 2-8 months based on location for a pretty much guaranteed denial. At that point some % drop out and the rest contact a lawyer and appeal. The appeal is just the same review done by a different person with a longer wait, this time between 6-12 months. It's also a near guaranteed denial.
After that you get the right to a hearing where you can actually present your case, which is where the vast majority of approvals occur.
